properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Dorian. The next full information statement will be issued by 9.00 a.m. ADT. The center of Post-Tropical cyclone Dorian tracked across central Nova Scotia last evening and is currently located over the Gulf of St. Lawrence northeast of the Magdalen Islands. Dorian will continue to track northeastward across the Gulf of St Lawrence this morning with powerful winds and heavy rainfall. Strong winds will slowly diminish over the Maritimes today and later today and tonight over Newfoundland and Labrador. 1. Summary of basic information at 6.00 a.m. ADT. The center of Post-Tropical Dorian was located near latitude 48.7 N longitude 60.8 W or about 157 km north-northeast of the Magdalen Islands. Dorian is still an intense Post-Tropical cyclone with maximum winds estimated at 70 knots...130 km/h and central pressure at 964 mb. Dorian is moving northeast at about 23 knots...43 km/h. 2. Summary of latest information. There were over 500,000 power outages across Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island. There have been countless reports of downed or uprooted trees, a large construction crane has collapsed in downtown Halifax, and storm surge flooding in several Atlantic coastal areas including Halifax Harbour, and along eastern coastlines in New Brunswick. Very strong winds were observed over Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, Iles de la Madeleine and western Newfoundland. Summerside PE reported a wind gust of 115 km/h, Iles de la Madeleine QC gusted to 120 km/h, and Stephenville and Port Aux Basques NL gusted to 104 km/h and 124 km/h respectively. Osborne Head near Halifax reported a wind gust to 141 km/h and Yarmouth reported a gust to 130 km/h. Many reports of heavy rainfall of 75 to 150 millimeters were observed over Nova Scotia, southeastern New Brunswick and western Prince Edward Island. Some offshore buoys reported wind gusts as high as 150 km/h and peak waves over 20 metres. Forecaster(s):Hatt ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-09-08T23:59:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-08T08:52:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1960594365.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Dorian. The next intermediate statement will be issued at 12:00 p.m. ADT. Followed by the full information statement issued at 03:00 p.m. ADT. The center of Post-Tropical cyclone Dorian is now over the northeastern Gulf of St Lawrence. Dorian will slowly weaken as it moves northeastward across northern Newfoundland later today and east of Labrador tonight. 1. Summary of basic information at 09:00 a.m. ADT. Location: Near 49.4 North 59.9 West. About: 190 km west-southwest of Daniels Harbour, Newfoundland. Maximum sustained winds: 130 kilometres per hour. Present movement: northeast at 43 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 964 millibars. 2. Public weather impacts and warnings summary. Dorian is currently moving through the northeastern Gulf of St Lawrence and is slowly weakening. However it is still producing high winds and heavy rain. Strong winds and heavy rain will continue to impact parts of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island, Newfoundland, the Magdalen Islands and the Quebec's Lower North Shore early this morning. Winds over parts of Nova Scotia and southwestern New Brunswick will continue to diminish this morning, and any remaining warnings there will be ended later today. Large waves and ocean swells will continue along the Atlantic coasts of Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and for eastern portions of the Gulf of St. Lawrence today. Elevated water levels and storm surge over parts of eastern New Brunswick will subside this morning. Elevated water levels are expected along Anticosti Island and parts of Quebec's Lower North Shore. Hurricane warnings will be ended this morning for eastern Nova Scotia but will be maintained for Newfoundland. The Tropical Storm warning will be ended for Prince Edward Island this morning. Tropical storm warnings are continued for parts of northern and southwestern Newfoundland, the Magdalen Islands and parts of Quebec's Lower North Shore. a. Wind. Many of the regions in and bordering the Gulf of St Lawrence will continue to be impacted by potentially damaging winds this morning. Wind impacts will likely be enhanced by foliage on the trees, causing broken branches, some tree falls, and power outages. The most likely areas will be for Cape Breton Island and western and northern Newfoundland. b. Rainfall. Rainfall warnings are continued the Gaspe Peninsula, and parts of the Quebec Lower North Shore. They will probably end the warnings later today or this evening. c. Surge/Waves. Storm surge warnings remain in effect for the Magdalen Islands as well as portions of southwestern Newfoundland. There will also be rough and pounding surf and large ocean swells, along the Atlantic coast of eastern Nova Scotia and southern coastlines of Newfoundland this morning, where waves of 6 to 10 metres are coming ashore. Waves of 4 to 8 metres will impact north facing coasts of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Note that waves will break higher along some of the coastlines, and dangerous rip currents are likely. Please exercise extreme caution. 3. Marine weather impacts and warnings summary. Hurricane force wind warnings remain in effect for most waters in and around the Gulf of St Lawrence. Storm and gale warnings are in effect for adjacent Maritimes waters, and for Newfoundland marine waters in the path or Dorian. Significant wave heights of 6 to 10 metres are occurring in offshore waters south of Nova Scotia, and these will move into the southwest coast of Newfoundland this morning. Waves of 4 to 7 metres will develop over Gulf of St Lawrence waters this morning. Late today into Monday waves will build to 4 to 7 metres, and up to near 5 metres over the Grand Banks. Forecasters: Mercer/Hatt ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-09-08T23:59:06-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong southwesterly winds with gusts to 110 km/h will develop along parts of the coast near noon today. Winds are expected to ease below warning criteria tonight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with severe and damaging gusts are expected or occurring. Post-tropical storm Dorian will continue to track northeastward through the Gulf of St. Lawrence today. Strong winds will gust as high as 100 km/h along parts of the coast this morning. Winds will then slowly diminish throughout the afternoon and evening as the storm departs. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may cause downed trees or toss loose objects. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds of 70 gusting to 100 km/h and possibly higher over exposed areas from Hurricane Dorian can be expected over the above regions. Tropical storm conditions are expected as Dorian quickly approaches and moves through the region. The current track has Dorian moving over the eastern Gulf of St. Lawrence this morning and then near the northern Peninsula this afternoon. Strong winds gusting up to 110 km/h are expected, especially along coastal areas. ### This could result in some damage to docks and breakwaters. Shoreline erosion and wave overwash is expected where winds blow onshore. A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are expected over parts of the region within 24 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-09T01:59:48-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds gusting to 100 km/h will ease to southeasterlies gusting to 70 km/h for an interval early this afternoon, but will be followed by strong southwesterlies with gusts to 110 km/h later this afternoon. Winds will diminish below warning criteria this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High Storm Surge levels and large waves are expected to impact the coast. The intense winds associated with post-tropical storm Dorian are forecast to generate large waves and storm surge for parts of the Gulf of St. Lawrence early this morning. Localized flooding due to storm surge and high waves are possible in the next few hours before the tide begins to ebb. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerous wind gusts causing widespread damage are expected or occurring. Strong southwesterly winds, with gusts reaching 150 km/h along parts of the coast, will ease below warning criteria late this afternoon or evening. ### Buildings under construction risk extreme damage. High winds may cause numerous downed trees and damage may occur from blowing debris. Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at high risk of being overturned. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall produced by post-tropical storm Dorian is still affecting Eastern Quebec. Total rainfall amounts will reach between 50 and 90 millimeters. The rain is expected to end by this afternoon over the Northeastern Gaspé Peninsula and late in the day over the Lower North Shore. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Hurricane Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hurricane force winds of 90 gusting to 130 km/h at exposed locations except 120 gusting to 150 km/h at the coast with surge of 0.7 to 1.0 m and waves from 4 to 7 m from Hurricane Dorian are expected. Hurricane conditions are expected to develop this morning as Dorian quickly approaches the region. The current track has Dorian moving over the eastern Gulf of St. Lawrence this morning and then over the northern Peninsula this afternoon. Winds gusting up to 150 km/h are expected, especially along coastal areas. ### These winds will topple many trees leading to downed utility lines and extended service outages. Moderate to significant damage to roofing materials, exterior cladding and light structures is likely. This could result in some damage to docks and breakwaters. Shoreline erosion and wave overwash is expected where winds blow onshore. A hurricane warning means that hurricane conditions are expected over parts of the region within 24 hours. Hurricane conditions include (A) sustained winds near 120 km/h or more, and/or (B) significantly elevated water levels and dangerous surf along the coast. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-09T01:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-08T13:33:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2978114603.2019

Description: High Storm Surge levels and large waves are expected to impact the coast. The intense winds associated with post-tropical storm Dorian are forecast to generate large waves and storm surge for parts of the Gulf of St. Lawrence early this morning. Localized flooding due to storm surge and high waves are possible in the next few hours before the tide begins to ebb. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-08T16:59:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-08T07:43:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2758030517.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada
